title: High Memory Usage v1.10.12-stable
body:
Geth version: 1.10.12-stable

OS & Version: Ubuntu

Experiencing unclean shutdowns from OOM every few hours because Geth keeps requiring more memory.  Following advice from a [prior thread](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/23195) and have uploaded a memory scan with --pprof;  [here](https://github.com/StakeNoob/mem-scan/blob/main/mem%20scan)

Followed Somer Esat Guide, running Lighthouse.

![grep warn](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/93400763/141697136-4d46d385-d181-4de7-a7ec-a16e7b042988.png)

What are the exact parameters you are  using to run the node? 
What are the hardware specs on the machine you're running it on?

Looks like the node has almost `2Gb` of transactions. ISTR we fixed something in the tx pool recently... investigating
```
big.Int                          27775312  1524.560 MB
types.DynamicFeeTx                2300551  1215.605 MB
trie.cachedNode                   1255759   801.626 MB
types.Transaction                 4598258   673.195 MB
types.LegacyTx                    2296672   622.265 MB
fastcache.Cache                         3   434.316 MB
```

> What are the exact parameters you are using to run the node?
What info do I need to provide here?

> What are the hardware specs on the machine you're running it on?
16GB Hyper X Impact Ram 3200Mhz, 1Tb Nvme Samsung EVO, Asus PN50 NUC

> What info do I need to provide here?

`geth --foo --bar --bazon=500 ... `. You can omit anything personal, like etherbase or mining address or extip if you're using that.

I get this;

`Incorrect Usage. flag provided but not defined: -foo`
What I mean is, what arguments are you using when you start geth?
`ExecStart=geth --http --datadir /var/lib/goethereum --cache 2048 --maxpeers 30 --pprof`

It's a bit odd. Are you sure it's geth that's hogging the memory? Do you see the OOMreaper in the syslogs of the machine? If so, what does it say about the memory consumption of geth?
Just speculating -- but in case there are N processes each hogging M Gb of data, the OOMReaper can select any one of those to reap to get more memory.

Does this help?

```
dmesg -T | egrep -i 'killed process'
[Tue Nov 16 16:27:49 2021] Out of memory: Killed process 41248 (geth) total-vm:15623388kB, anon-rss:12596728kB, file-rss:0kB, shmem-rss:0kB, UID:1002 pgtables:26672kB oom_score_adj:0
[Tue Nov 16 19:27:43 2021] Out of memory: Killed process 42925 (geth) total-vm:16456596kB, anon-rss:12839812kB, file-rss:0kB, shmem-rss:0kB, UID:1002 pgtables:27640kB oom_score_adj:0
```

I follow very prescribed guides as staking was my first introduction to linux.  When I had less than 50gb to prune I got some help removing db manually on the discord - this is the only other variable outside of Somer Esat guide.  Other than that I don't know if a delay in updating might have created an issue?

> Does this help?

Yes, it shows (I think) that geth reached around `16G` before it was killed. The memprofile you uploaded shows nowhere nearly that much, but the `dmesg` makes it clear.

The scan provided doesn't really show anything out of the ordinary. This may be just because it was taken at a time when not much memory was allocated -- could you please try again, and see if you manage to take a memory dump at a point close to when it is going OOM?

![new htop](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/93400763/142662830-89d8cc26-1a0e-4f45-9b67-4bed996a9dee.png)
I waited until my RAM was nearly maxed when taking the scan,this was my htop just before. Not long after I got OOM.   I can still do another scan if you like, but the discrepancy doesn't seem right.

So, in the first screenshot, you have only included level `WARN` and above. Could you provide some more logs, with the lower levels included? 

>  I can still do another scan if you like, but the discrepancy doesn't seem right.

Doesn't sound like it will help, seems like the mem scanner is unable to locate the memory leak.

![fail error grep](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/93400763/143618853-416322de-b4ca-462e-ab4c-d744dcdddd58.png)
Helpful?
A bit, yes -- seems you are in the middle of a sync? Please provide the logs as text, without grepping for things.

I've been trying a few things not quite sure how to get what you are after.  I tried this;

`curl -X POST localhost:8545 -H "Content-Type: application/json" --data-raw '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"eth_syncing","id":1}'
{"jsonrpc":"2.0","id":1,"result":{"currentBlock":"0xc801c2","highestBlock":"0xd0ebc8","knownStates":"0x2c18346f","pulledStates":"0x2c18346f","startingBlock":"0xc87c0a"}}`

I can't find the log file, if it has left one.
I mean just the logs. `sudo journalctl -u geth --since=today`, and maybe pipe it into something you can upload to this ticket.
Pasted in a repository [here](https://github.com/StakeNoob/Geth-Journalctl-Today/blob/8b3d3bf7f7629d0fa2b015556fd8a36b82e0fdb4/README.md)

Interested in this bug as well, may be seeing the same issue. Geth “10.12 stable” runs for 1-3 days then crashes with OOM error. 

Trying to do a full sync and then operate as a node. Have tried increasing cache values ranging from 5-10GB but every few days it still crashes. (Geth limits to 5GB anyways)

Hardware is dedicated to only running Geth. Xeon 3.4GHz 6C/6T processor, 16GB of RAM, 8 TB SSD (dual 4GB in RAID 0). OS is Ubuntu Server 20.04, no GUI just command line.

@StakeNoob thanks, that helped a lot!

```
Nov 27 01:33:22 EthStaker geth[235026]: INFO [11-27|01:33:22.673] Loaded most recent local header          number=13,107,650 hash=5fdac7..2c1bc8 td=29,614,342,018,010,984,500,618 age=3mo15h25m
Nov 27 01:33:22 EthStaker geth[235026]: INFO [11-27|01:33:22.673] Loaded most recent local full block      number=13,107,650 hash=5fdac7..2c1bc8 td=29,614,342,018,010,984,500,618 age=3mo15h25m
Nov 27 01:33:22 EthStaker geth[235026]: INFO [11-27|01:33:22.673] Loaded most recent local fast block      number=13,107,650 hash=5fdac7..2c1bc8 td=29,614,342,018,010,984,500,618 age=3mo15h25m
```
So you have block `13107650`/`0x5fdac7...` as most recent, however, canonical block [13107650](https://etherscan.io/block/13107650) has hash `0x74d36a16e65fe50d90878e83d8be09f09f89482d8f981d6f86e65bf329f004d7`

Then it goes into a mode where it finds the (canonical?) chain, and starts to import that
```
Importing heavy sidechain segment        blocks=908 start=13,070,159 end=13,071,066
```

This means it will have to import `13107650 - 13070159 = 37491` blocks before the 'sidechain' will swap out the one you have. 

That's what it keeps doing until it goes OOM, and restarting again at the same point: 
```
Nov 27 04:13:24 EthStaker geth[236799]: INFO [11-27|04:13:24.175] Loaded most recent local header          number=13,107,650 hash=5fdac7..2c1bc8 td=29,614,342,018,010,984,500,618 age=3mo18h5m
Nov 27 04:13:24 EthStaker geth[236799]: INFO [11-27|04:13:24.175] Loaded most recent local full block      number=13,107,650 hash=5fdac7..2c1bc8 td=29,614,342,018,010,984,500,618 age=3mo18h5m
Nov 27 04:13:24 EthStaker geth[236799]: INFO [11-27|04:13:24.175] Loaded most recent local fast block      number=13,107,650 hash=5fdac7..2c1bc8 td=29,614,342,018,010,984,500,618 age=3mo18h5m
Nov 27 04:13:24 EthStaker geth[236799]: INFO [11-27|04:13:24.176] Loaded last fast-sync pivot marker       number=12,401,481
```

This looks really odd -- because on mainnet, I can't imagine that there exists any sidechain with `37K` valid blocks, so I'm very curious what happened here. 


In order to fix this, a couple of things can be done. Your pivot point is `12401481`, so there should be plenty of points to go back to before `13070159`. So doing a the following in a geth console would most likely solve the problem for you:
```
debug.setHead(13070159)
``` 
In order to do it 'cleanly' might be best to first stop geth, then start geth in non-peering mode (to not trigger a new sync)
```
geth <args> --nodiscover --maxpeers 0 console
...
$> debug.setHead(13070159)
```
That will make geth rewind, and you should be able to sync up properly afterwards. 


However, I'm a bit curious about what you actually have in your blockchain. If you would provide me with this blocks, I would be interested in investigating them. They can be extracted in RLP-form via this command:
```
geth export blocks.rlp 13070159 13107650
```
(and, of course, that needs to be done _before_ you rewind the chain)

I don't know if this is what you expected, if there is a need for more tests I can hold off on rewind.

`INFO [11-29|16:59:40.402] Maximum peer count                       ETH=50 LES=0 total=50
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.403] Smartcard socket not found, disabling    err="stat /run/pcscd/pcscd.comm: no such file or directory"
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.406] Set global gas cap                       cap=50,000,000
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.406] Allocated cache and file handles         database=/home/henry/.ethereum/geth/chaindata cache=512.00MiB handles=524,288
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.500] Opened ancient database                  database=/home/henry/.ethereum/geth/chaindata/ancient readonly=false
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.506] Disk storage enabled for ethash caches   dir=/home/henry/.ethereum/geth/ethash count=3
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.506] Disk storage enabled for ethash DAGs     dir=/home/henry/.ethash               count=2
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.507] Loaded most recent local header          number=0 hash=d4e567..cb8fa3 td=17,179,869,184 age=52y8mo16h
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.507] Loaded most recent local full block      number=0 hash=d4e567..cb8fa3 td=17,179,869,184 age=52y8mo16h
INFO [11-29|16:59:40.507] Loaded most recent local fast block      number=0 hash=d4e567..cb8fa3 td=17,179,869,184 age=52y8mo16h
WARN [11-29|16:59:40.508] Loaded snapshot journal                  diskroot=d7f897..0f0544 diffs=missing
Fatal: Export error: block number 13107650 larger than head block 0`
![eth block export](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/93400763/143911405-5d951cb6-fbbd-4860-bc6c-0a620e46e245.png)

Yeah, when I wrote `<args>` I meant that things like datadir. In your case, I think you're using `/var/lib/goethereum/geth/` normally? If so: 

```
geth --datadir /var/lib/goethereum/geth/ export blocks.rlp 13070159 13107650
````

![gethsethead](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/93400763/144092719-28277f89-b216-45f0-85e8-83cb5fabcf15.png)
Done sudo systemctl stop geth, then ran into trouble with the debug command.

I exported the blocks, >3.3Gb. What is preferred recourse for you when too large for Github?

> I exported the blocks, >3.3Gb. What is preferred recourse for you when too large for Github?

Hm, I guess we don't actually need _all_ of that, perhaps it would be sufficient to peek at a few megabytes or so, and see what those blocks are. Perhaps you can upload a couple of megabytes from the beginning of it to github? 

Something like `cut -b 1-3000000 blocks.rlp > blocks.3mb.rlp`
Oh, and thanks for helping out with this, I appreciate it!

> then ran into trouble with the debug command.

Yes, my bad. It doesn't take integers, but hex strings. So `debug.setHead("0xc76f4f")` should work better

So I entered 

`cut -b 1-3000000 blocks.rlp > blocks.3mb.rlp` like you said, but the file is 3.1GB!  So we need something much smaller, I tried knocking 2 zeros off, hope I haven't screwed up because the file size has not changed.  The number relates to a starting point rather than number of blocks being cut?

Man no problem, but it seems too early to assume that I'm actually helpful yet - lol!  Thanks for being patient with me.

Sorry, my bad again. Use this instead
```
head -c 3000000 blocks.rlp > blocks.3mb.rlp 
```

Brilliant, thank you! [blocks3mb](https://github.com/StakeNoob/blocks3mb/blob/55e2f70dc53a2241d517392b6f16f837ec71734f/blocks.3mb.rlp)

So Geth rewound in like a minute, faster than I thought;

![geth rewind](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/93400763/144494157-a18a5615-61de-4c0d-85bb-146d22176436.png)

Granted all is well I should sync properly if go back into peering mode.  Should I just journalctl start geth, edit system md file back to 30 peers if needed?
